subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Reith, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.
The purpose of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Repeal Bill 1999 is to repeal the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act 1946.
In 1998, a detailed review of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act was undertaken pursuant to the government's legislation review schedule.

The need to review the act was first identified in 1995 by the then Labor government as part of its development of a regulation review timetable following on from the national Competition Principles Agreement signed by all governments in April of that year.

The legislation review found that the government's training reform process, in particular the development of training packag es and the introduction of the Australian Recognition Framework, has removed the ongoing need and rationale for the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act.

The report of the legislation review concluded that registered training organisations established under the Australian Recognition Framework are better able to provide trade skills assessment services and there is no longer any need for the Commonwealth to do so. The report recommends that the act be repealed.

The year 1996 saw the 50th anniversary of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. At that time, I noted that for 50 years, it had played an important role in helping to meet Australia's trades skill needs, predominantly in the metal and electrical trades.

After the Second World War, it aided in the task of re-settling returning troops into the civilian work force and reconstructing Australia's economy. It also allowed people who developed their trade skills in industry during the war to receive the appropriate recognition for those skills.

By 1951, it was considered that the legislation had achieved its immediate post-war objectives and the act was amended to also provide for the recognition of the trades skills of migrants after they arrive in Australia. Since then, newly arrived migrants have been the main client group seeking to have their skills recognised under the legislation.

The value of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has been the nationally accepted trade qualification issued under it. Until the introduction in 1998 of the Australian Recognition Framework, there was no alternative national mechanism due to a lack of uniformity in trade training and recognition systems at the state level. Consequently, the act provided a means for the national recognition and mobility of skills that did not otherwise exist.

The importance of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act in this regard was reinforced by a review of the act undertaken in 1991 by Mr B.H. Tregillis. The Tregillis review recommended that the act should continue `until national standards and processes have been developed and unless and until it can be demonstrated that a more effective mechanism [than the act] can be put in place'.
The conditions for repealing the act identified by the Tregillis review have been met by the development of training packages and the Australian Recognition Framework.
In November 1996, Commonwealth, state and territory Ministers for Vocational Education and Training endorsed the National Training Framework.

The aims of the National Training Framework are to provide a more flexible and simpler regulatory environment for training and to underpin the user choice arrangements of the government's New Apprenticeships initiative.
The National Training Framework comprises two elements—training packages and the Australian Recognition Framework.
Training packages are developed by industry to provide the basis for the delivery of training and the assessment of skills on a consistent national basis.

The Australian Recognition Framework devolves the delivery of training and the issuing of qualifications to registered training organisations which operate under a quality assurance framework administered by the states and territories.

At 30 June 1998 there were 195,500 apprentices and trainees in training throughout Australia. More than 60,000 of these were in trades covered by the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. The Australian Recognition Framework governs the way these and future apprentices and trainees are trained and have their skills recognised.

The legislation review notes that the importance of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has been declining in comparison to the domestic training system, and in absolute terms for some time. In 1997-98 there were only 1,218 applications for trades skill recognition under the act. The Legislation Review notes that much of the recent decline in demand for recognition under the act reflects the changes that have occurred in the domestic training system.

It is appropriate that the Australian Recognition Framework, which governs the operation of the domestic training system for nearly 200,000 apprentices and trainees, also applies in the recognition of the trades skills of little more than 1,200 applicants under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act.

The legislation review concludes that the services provided under the act can now be delivered on a nationally consistent and competitive basis by registered training organisations under the Australian Recognition Framework, and that the continuation of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act would be inconsistent with the training reform agenda which is supported by all levels of government and industry.

The legislation review committee consulted widely in the course of the review, and the action it has recommended is strongly supported, including by the Australian National Training Authority, state and territory government training authorities, and the Australian Chamber of Industry and Commerce.

In its comments on an interim report circulated by the review committee, the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia said that it `appreciates that the time has come to repeal the [Tradesmen's Rights Regulation] Act'.

The government accepts the legislation review's findings. This is not about cost savings. The services provided under the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act have been increasingly self-funding since the introduction of fees by the Hawke Government in 1989, and the savings accruing to the Commonwealth from the act's repeal will be less than $500,000 per annum.

The Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act has played a valuable role, but with the advent of recent domestic training reforms that provide a more appropriate and efficient alternative, that role has come to an end.

This bill constitutes the necessary first step in implementing the recommendations of the review. The second step is the promulgation of regulations to ensure a smooth transition to the new arrangements and, in particular, safeguard the rights of persons who currently have an application in the system. A communication strategy will ensure that all stakeholders fully understand both the transitional and new arrangements.

In closing, I would like to acknowledge the contribution made by a very great many people over the past 50 years to the operation of the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act. I commend the bill to the House and present its explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martin Ferguson) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That, with effect from 11 May 1999, standing order 275A be amended to read

275A Notwithstanding standing order 275, when the Main Committee meets before 10 a.m. the Chair shall first call statements by Members. A Member, other than a Minister, may be called by the Chair to make a statement for a period not exceeding 3 minutes. The period for Members' statements may continue for a maximum of 18 minutes or until 10 a.m. whichever is the earlier. For the purpose of this standing order a Minister does not include a Parliamentary Secretary.

I do not intend to delay the House for more than a moment. The change which we are proposing today provides for two very simple changes to House standing order 275A. They are essentially to extend the three-minute members' statements which currently occur at 9.40 on Thursday mornings to Wednesday mornings as well and to allow parliamentary secretaries an opportunity to speak in members' statements—an opportunity which is currently denied them by the standing orders.

In December 1997 we introduced sessional orders providing for three-minute members' statements on Thursdays and an adjournment debate in the Main Committee. The trials of both were successful and last year, in the middle of the year, we placed them in the standing orders. The continuing usefulness of that new system prompts us to the changes we are proposing today. I make the point that members' statements only take place when the Main Committee is sitting. It sits when there is business with which it must deal. When it does not have business then it does not sit, and that is the practice today, as it has been since its introduction.

This will simply provide an opportunity for parliamentary secretaries to make members' statements. It will allow them by and large to address constituency matters and provides a forum for them. To ensure that there is no diminution in the time available for private members, we are proposing the additional time on the extra day a week. So I think that is a fair balance and it does provide for those members an opportunity to carry out their representative duties. I hope that it has the support of the House. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the motion. We are gradually moving forward in the development of practices in the Main Committee. This is another step forward. I do not think anyone thinks this will be the end of the evolution of the use of the Main Committee, but it is a step which has two effects. One is to provide more opportunities for backbench members, opposition members and now parliamentary secretaries to speak in the Main Committee. That provision can only be beneficial to members. There is no downside to that. The other is the extension of that right to parliamentary secretaries. I have to say that I support that for two reasons.

speech.para: The first is that, from a purely opposition point of view, there is no cost to us. It is a question of how the government divides its time, and for future governments that will be the same. Were we to be the government at this stage it would be a matter for us to choose whether or not we took it up, but it does not in any way interfere with opposition members' time. So we are quite comfortable about saying that this is all plus for us.

talk.start.para: —The second reason, as my colleague the member for Perth so rudely interjected, is that I remember the frustration of being a parliamentary secretary—

—As does the member for Brisbane. And I remember the evolution of the function of parliamentary secretaries through the Senate standing orders, which was in some ways for me much too rapid, because it enabled all the worst things to be done by parliamentary secretaries but none of the best. Nevertheless, this is a proper extension. Parliamentary secretaries are also members of the House and have constituency responsibilities and issues they wish to raise and few opportunities to do so, so I support the change in the standing orders. I think it is a small step, but it is a step in the right direction and we support it.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the parliamentary secretaries, I thank the House for the motion that was just carried. I move:

speech.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of Darwin Naval Base Project, Darwin, Northern Territory.

The Department of Defence proposes to redevelop Darwin naval base to overcome facilities inadequacies affecting current operations and to cater for a planned increase in the number of minor war vessels to be home ported at Darwin. The base is an element of the Larrakeyah Barracks, and its initial development was completed in 1982. It was designed to support six Fremantle class patrol boats to be home ported in Darwin and to support other naval operational and exercise activities in northern waters.

Since 1982 the tempo of operational activities in the north has increased, as has the intensity of unilateral and bilateral exercises. Four Army landing craft and additional naval heavy landing craft and additional harbour support craft have been relocated to Darwin, placing an unacceptable strain on the existing support facilities. To support the increases in activity and the additional craft, works were undertaken in 1992 to expand the dry berth tie down area and in 1993 works were undertaken to supplement administrative and workshop facilities. Navy intends to further increase the number of minor war vessels to be home ported in Darwin. An additional four patrol boats and another heavy landing craft will be relocated to Darwin on completion of the proposed works.

The predominant elements of the work will be the extension of the existing wharf to cater for landing craft, the construction of a new wharf to support patrol boats and visiting minor war vessels, extension of the dry land storage area to facilitate repair activities and to increase the base's capacity to protect craft in the event of a cyclone and increased fuel treatment and storage facilities to cater for home ported vessels. Inadequacies in office and stores areas will also be addressed.

The estimated turnout cost of the project is $12.4 million. Subject to parliamentary approval, the project will be committed in September 1999 with the objective of completion of work by June in the year 2001. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's interim report entitled Visit to Bougainville 15-18 March 1999 .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave—On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I have great pleasure today in presenting the report of a visit to Port Moresby and Bougainville made by a delegation from the committee from 15 to 18 March 1999. The report is an interim one in the sense that the visit was conducted as an integral part of the committee's current inquiry into the Bougainville peace process and a later, full report to parliament is foreshadowed. That report will include specific recommendations on the basis of the formal evidence which the committee is in the process of gathering. The report I present today describes the program of meetings, informal discussions and inspections which the delegation conducted during our recent visit. The report also outlines the delegation's observations and presents some preliminary views and conclusions.

speech.para: Within the limitations imposed by time and distance, the delegation's program was a busy one. The delegation met with most of the key participants in the peace process, except for the resistance leaders, who were unfortunately not in Bougainville at the time of the visit. The delegation members had an invaluable opportunity to be exposed to a very broad range of perspectives, and we were able to see for ourselves the actual situation in Bougainville.

Apart from the enormous human tragedies of the war in Bougainville, there has been an almost total destruction of the province's political, economic and social infrastructure. Restoration of basic communications and reconstruction of health, education and other essential services are huge tasks which will take many years and will require considerable ongoing external aid. The committee report comments on a number of Australian aid programs in Bougainville and highlights some areas where additional assistance might be needed.

From the visit, the delegation gained considerable insights into the problems being faced in advancing the peace process. While travelling around Bougainville, the delegates were able to observe first-hand some of the evidence of the destruction that has resulted from the war—for example, the rusting remains of destroyed buildings, abandoned or overgrown homes and plantations.

Our meetings and discussions gave the delegation confidence that the peace process has almost universal support and that the next phase will concentrate on determining the mechanisms for restoring civil administration. The delegation was pleased to note that, since mid-1997, a great deal of progress has been made towards resolving the protracted conflict in Bougainville. Today, Bougainville is relatively calm and, although there have been isolated killings, there has been no major fighting for almost two years. The daily lives of Bougainvilleans are beginning to return to normal, and freedom of movement has considerably improved. However, there is only limited trading and other commercial activities in evidence, apart perhaps from a brisk trade in scrap materials. As elsewhere in Papua New Guinea, there are law and order problems in some areas of Bougainville.

After more than nine years of violence and armed conflict, the momentum for peace appears to be firmly on the agenda for the people of Bougainville and their leaders, despite occasional setbacks. There are very positive signs that the peace dividend is showing results in very practical ways and that the peace process is continuing to move forward.

In conjunction with other regional countries, Australia has made a major contribution to advancing the peace process through political and diplomatic efforts, through Australia's very large aid program to Papua New Guinea, and through the work of the peace monitoring group. Australia's pivotal role, in conjunction with other regional countries in encouraging the momentum for peace, is acknowledged. However, there is potential danger in becoming complacent about the progress towards peace. Continual vigilance is needed to maintain a focus on the desired outcome of enabling Bougainvilleans themselves, in partnership with the central government, to determine their own future. This outcome is in Australia's national interest as well.

The delegation wishes to thank the Papua New Guinea government, in particular the Speaker of the national parliament, the Hon. John Pundari MP, and senior government ministers for extending the invitation to the delegation, for their courtesy and hospitality during the visit and for the opportunities to exchange views quite freely. These thanks extend also to senior opposition members and to the Bougainvillean leaders and community groups. Their contribution to the discussions and the frankness with which views were able to be exchanged were very much appreciated by the delegates.

The delegation wishes to express its sincere appreciation to the Australian High Commissioner in Port Moresby, His Excellency Mr David Irvine, and his staff for the assistance provided both before and during the visit. All the arrangements made for the busy program were excellent and contributed significantly to the success of the visit. The delegation also expresses grateful thanks to the former commander of the PMG, Brigadier Bruce Osborn, ADF, who accompanied the delegation throughout the visit and who provided valuable insights into the role of the PMG and its contribution to the peace process.

The delegation travelled to and from PNG by means of regular RAAF supply flights undertaken by No. 37 Squadron. In every sense, these arrangements were excellent. The efforts of the flight crew were very much appreciated by all the members of the delegation. In Bougainville, the PMG provided air, sea and land transportation for the delegation as well as detailed briefings and overall facilitation of the visit program. To the commander, Brigadier Roger Powell, and to all the PMG personnel, the delegation expresses its grateful thanks for their professionalism, enthusiasm and support during the visit. Finally, I would like to thank the deleg ation members for their assistance during and after the visit. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —by leave—As deputy chairman of the committee and of the delegation, I would like to applaud all the comments made by the honourable member for Fadden and also congratulate the members of the delegation for the work they did. I also want to emphasise the importance of the peace monitoring group which is, I think, quite unique in terms of peacekeeping groups around the world, and it is doing a tremendous job. I think it is true to say that the group, which is primarily Australian orientated in terms of participation, although there are people from Vanuatu, Fiji and New Zealand, is doing an excellent job on the ground. I believe, and I think most Bougainvilleans believe, that without that group on the ground doing that job we would not have proceeded as far as we have in terms of the peace in that situation.

speech.para: The political discussions that we had both in Bougainville and in Port Moresby reinforced the view that, although significant differences exist about Bougainville's political future, people are determined to try to achieve and continue on the path of peace. One of the factors which is most important in relation to that path of peace is the forthcoming election, which is due to be held in mid-April. Whether it will be held in mid-April is not clear yet, but that election is of critical importance to the future of Bougainville.

Interestingly, most groups in Bougainville wish to participate in that electoral process, although there are some that are raising objections of a constitutional nature to it. It is very important that Australia encourage the election to proceed, and the report actually says that, notwithstanding the fact that there has not been total disarmament, we nevertheless support the idea of these elections proceeding so that an interim assembly and government can be formed for Bougainville whose major purpose will be to negotiate a political settlement with the government of Papua New Guinea in terms of outcomes.

This leads me to the other matter which I think is very important if there is going to be political agreement in both Papua New Guinea and Bougainville. That is, it is important for proposals to be put forward in relation to an autonomy package for the province—that is to say, proposals about the kind of constitution that will exist for the province and the kinds of powers which the regional Bougainvillean government is going to have vis-a-vis the central government.

Most of the people we spoke to, even those who were not supportive of this election—such as the opposition at the national level—agreed that it was very important to develop these proposals for an autonomy package. I think this is the factor which, after the elections in April, will determine whether or not the people of Bougainville can come together in a unified way and also whether a resolution can be made with the government of Papua New Guinea. Australia should do whatever it can to assist politically to ensure that this process is further developed. In fact, if there is anything Australia can do in providing expertise to assist this political process, we ought to do so.

The key players in the Bougainville crisis have all committed themselves, as the member for Fadden said, to a path of peace. They no longer want war. They want to redevelop Bougainville and they want to go forward to provide the basics of health, education, transport and many other ordinary things of life for their people. They have recognised that, notwithstanding their differences of a political and constitutional nature, they want to develop Bougainville and they do not want to return to the destructive path which existed before. The vast majority of people support the idea of some kind of election which will be fair and democratic. In this respect, I hope the elections will proceed in this way and achieve that aim.
One of the chiefs in Haku gave us a copy of his speech, and I think it is worth reading the closing part of it to sum up the aspirations of the people of Bougainville. He said:

We are asking all leaders not to play politics with our future. Peace is so close and yet so easily thrown away by a careless word. We ask for your support for the peace process as agreed so far. Please do not look for reasons why this process cannot work. Join hands with us to help it work, to make it work. Join hands with us to help the people of Bougainville and their families and their children to enjoy the peace that you happily can take for granted. Do not help those who would tear down what we have built so far. All we ask is that you give peace a chance.
I think that sums up the aspirations of the people of Bougainville. This is a very important report and I commend it to all members.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the House take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The aim of the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 is to bring the Navigation Act into line with the Workplace Relations Act and to modernise the act, especially now that company employment applies in the shipping industry. If Australia is to have a competitive shipping industry, reform of the shipping legislation to make it an efficient regulatory tool is essential. This bill is the first stage of that reform, and those who oppose it are sending a message that they oppose a future for the industry.

speech.para: Judging from the debate, the opposition have either misunderstood or deliberately misrepresented the content and impact of the bill. Despite the many hours of debate afforded to the opposition, they have not come up with one single reason to substantiate the claims they have made against the bill.

Contrary to what the opposition have said, the bill will not compromise safety, will not expose Australian seafarers to abuse, will not facilitate the use of forged certificates, will not open up the coast and waterfront to cheap foreign labour and will not have any of the other ill-informed results claimed by the opposition. The bill simply removes a whole lot of archaic and unnecessary legislation that gets in the way of productive relationships between employers and their employees entering into genuine company employment. The bill does not in any way affect the safety of Australian seafarers, nor does it affect the issues raised in the Ships of shame or Ship safe reports.

The current powers given to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to deal with unseaworthy and substandard ships will not be affected by the bill. The rights of Australian seafarers to refuse to sail on an unseaworthy or substandard ship will remain, as will remedies to recover unpaid wages. Despite claims to the contrary by the opposition, the rights of Australian masters and seamen for wages and repatriation in the event of shipwreck, loss or bankruptcy are being retained.

Suggestions that the employment conditions of Australian seafarers will decline as a result of the amendments to the act are not credible. Australian seafarers enjoy some of the best employment conditions in the world. While some seafarers' conditions are currently set out in detail in the Navigation Act itself, for other industries they are contained in workplace agreements. With the move to company employment of seafarers, there is absolutely no reason to retain the conditions in the Navigation Act. They can be included in employment agreements between seafarers and the companies which employ them.

The bill is not aimed at reducing safety standards and will not have that effect. AMSA retains all of its powers through marine orders made under the Navigation Act to require the production of qualification certificates. Also, section 16 of the act covering the problems of forged certificates is being retained and is not affected by the amendments in the bill. The bill has no implications for the employment of foreign seafarers in Australia whose employment, like all other foreign workers, is determined by the provisions of the Migration Act.

While the bill is amending provisions of the Navigation Act, it is not amending the substance of Australia's cabotage regime. The only amendment is the removal of an archaic provision relating to access to ship's libraries. Removing the compulsory requirement for articles of agreement increases the flexibility of employees and employers to enter into agreements best suited to the differing operations of individual companies.

If the Australian shipping industry is to survive and I guess prosper, it must be efficient and competitive. The legislative tools which regulate the industry must also be efficient and in line with modern practice. These amendments remove inconsistencies between the Navigation Act and the Workplace Relations Act. They bring the industry into line with other industries in this country and, given that company employment has now been adopted in the shipping industry, they remove totally unnecessary and restrictive employment practices.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I understand it is the wish of the House to take the bill as a whole.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, there is a range of items that the opposition will be opposing, some we will be supporting, and three that we are seeking to move amendments to.
—As I understand it, you are now going to ask leave of the House to move amendments Nos 1 to 3 as circulated in your name. Is that correct?
—Yes.
—Have we agreed to deal with the bill as a whole?

—I was not aware of that, but in terms of voting on the clauses there are some that the opposition is willing to support and there are a number of clauses that we intend to oppose. I was not aware of any discussions on this matter. I would have proposed that we dealt with some of those items in the block in which they conform to that formula. For example, the first five items we will be opposing; items Nos 6 and 7 we will be supporting. I would have thought it better to deal with items 1 to 5 in a block—that is, together—and then to deal with the others in a similar way as we progress through the bill. I am just trying to ensure that we have got a process we all understand.

—If you want to take the bill as a whole, you can still move your amendments and, if you wish to divide on any of those amendments, we can deal with those separately. For the ease of the House—if the minister is agreeable—if we take the bill as a whole and then you move your amendments, the amendments can be debated and then the amendments put. If you want to divide on any or all of those amendments, you can do that.

—The dilemma is not dealing with the amendments separately. There are a number of items that we are opposing that are not the subject of amendments. We simply oppose those items. There are a number of items which I have indicated we would be willing to support. If the bill was taken as a whole, there would be one vote on the bill rather than votes clause by clause, which would then leave the opposition in the position of determining whether we want to support the bill as a whole as distinct from consideration of the specific items.

—My understanding is that there have been some agreements made about this legislation and an acknowledgment that the opposition has both some amendments and some opposition to components of the bill. Because of the circumstances today, I do not think it is intended to divide in this place on the issues. It was my understanding that the opposition having moved its amendments and the government responding in each case it would have the right to identify other areas which it opposed so that it stated its position in this place. The bill then, of course, would be carried on the voices, but the opposition would have made its position clear for any future Senate debate. If I could recommend that as the process we should follow, we could carry on with this to the convenience of a number of people.

—To make life easier, I am happy to proceed on the basis that we consider the bill in detail as a whole. The amendments can probably be dealt with together rather than separately. I will then during my contributions refer to specific items that we are opposing and supporting, and that might facilitate the process.
—by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 1 to 3:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 10, page 4 (lines 12 and 13), omit the item, substitute:
Omit `or ballast'.
(2) Schedule 1, item 14, page 5 (lines 1 and 2), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the subsections.
(3) Schedule 1, item 47, omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the paragraphs.

We have just heard a response from the government to some of those matters that were raised in the course of the second reading debate. I want to make a couple of comments about the process that the parliament has adopted in dealing with the Navigation Amendment (Employment of Seafarers) Bill 1998 . This bill had a number of speakers listed from the Labor side who in fact did speak on the matter. From memory, there were only two government members who spoke on the bill and indicated an interest in it. We were confronted with a situation where the government said that either we referred this bill to the Main Committee or we would have the gag applied to us and the Labor members of parliament would be denied the opportunity to speak on the bill. As a consequence, we agreed to the matter being moved from the House of Representatives chamber to the Main Committee.

At the outset, I want to place on the record my concern about that process. The Main Committee was devised to deal with matters agreed by both sides of the House to be non-controversial. This bill is anything but non-controversial. It is a precedent that should not be followed. The Main Committee was not designed to deal with legislation of this kind. In introducing my remarks about the bill in consideration in detail, I first want to place on the record the opposition's concern that, in future, matters of this kind should be dealt with properly in the chamber, as has always been the case.

I also want to make it clear that there are a number of provisions of this bill which the opposition have very serious concerns about and outright opposition to. It is a bill that touches on some 80-odd different provisions in the act. Some of those can be fairly complex. The issues surrounding the bill are also complex, and it will be our intention in the Senate to have this matter carefully scrutinised there and provide the public and all of the stakeholders with an opportunity to make a contribution to the debate. That is particularly important given the procedure the government has followed so far.

The government has set about changing the rules on the waterfront and in the seafaring industry without consulting all the stakeholders. It has set up inquiries and ensured that the only people on those inquiries were business operators in the industry. There has not been a consultation process that the opposition regards as satisfactory. Indeed, the government's own parliamentary committee, in a report to this parliament, criticised the consultation process followed with regard to reform in the seafaring industry and identified it as having been unsatisfactory. That is a view held by a bipartisan committee of this parliament. For the government to proceed with the bill on the basis of that inadequate and flawed consultation is in itself a matter of concern. I guess that goes hand in hand with its attitude of referring the matter to the Main Committee or gagging debate on it.

The third observation I make at the outset is that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who introduced the bill, apparently has other commitments that prevent him from being here. I would have thought the Minister for Transport and Regional Services would have wanted to be here for the second reading debate and the consideration in detail stage of the bill. It may be that as the surrogate minister for the bill he does not see it as his responsibility. I say `surrogate minister' because this bill was introduced in the last parliament not by the transport minister but by the industrial relations minister, and that is precisely what this bill is about: it is about industrial relations. It is about the working conditions of those people employed in the seafaring industry. I guess the surrogate minister who now has responsibility for it feels more comfortable not being here and throwing the hospital pass to somebody else.

I made a comment during the course of the second reading debate that there were some three reports of this parliament in a period of six years that had looked at this industry and that there is no industry I can think of that has been subject to such scrutiny by the parliament. (Extension of time granted) I made an error when I made that comment. There have not been three reports in the last six years; there have been four reports in the last six years. There were the three Ships of shame reports produced during the period of Labor government from 1992 to 1996 and, since the 1996 election, there has been the report tabled at the end of last year by the committee chaired by Mr Neville.

So we have had four reports dealing with the concerns of this industry, all of them identifying major flaws and difficulties in conducting a fair and proper seafaring industry in a deregulated environment. Against all of that evidence, and against the conclusions of each and every one of those committees and their recommendations, this government now pursues a bill which seeks to deregulate the Australian seafaring industry and expose it to the very perils that those four reports have identified. Those reports went full bore, straight up and down, to the matters confronted in this legislation.

For example, the most recent of those reports in 1998 referred to crew welfare, which is precisely the matter dealt with in the abolition of articles of agreement proposed in this bill. The 1998 Ship safe report, from the committee that was composed of a majority of Liberal and National Party members and senators, said:
In all the focus areas before the committee in this inquiry, crew welfare appears to have progressed the least in the 1990s, and much remains in need of improvement.
That was the advice to this parliament from an all-party committee just last year. They said that there are problems and, in their words, `much remains in need of improvement'.

This government's response to that conclusion and recommendation from its own parliamentary committee is not to set about improving the problems; it is not to set about addressing the crew welfare difficulties that the report has given us advice of. The government's response is to strip away the existing protections, to take away those things in the law that presently protect Australian seafarers. That is the response the government has given to that advice. Instead of a response such as, `There is a major problem—in fact, of all the things we have looked at, we think crew welfare is the biggest problem, and it is getting worse, and the government needs to improve the protection in this area,' this government adopts exactly the opposite course.

We heard a comment from the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, who is at the table, on behalf of the government that this bill was not about reducing workers' rights. There are a few simple facts that need to be stated. We are at the moment in breach of ILO conventions in respect of seafarers. That point has been made by the parliament's treaties committee, again at a time since this government took office. That committee has a majority of government members. Their advice to the parliament is that we are in breach of the ILO conventions now.

If this bill is carried, we will be in further breach of ILO conventions. Why would you be in breach of ILO conventions? The answer is because you failed to provide the minimum standards for labour relation matters that the ILO has set down. It is absolutely an attack upon the working conditions and rights of those Australians employed as seafarers in the industry. That is precisely what this bill does. That is precisely why this bill was introduced by Mr Reith, the then Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, prior to the last election.

It is simply a quirk of cabinet reshuffling that it is now before us under the transport portfolio. I imagine that, after the fiasco of Patrick and Dubai, the Prime Minister thought well to remove that area of responsibility from Mr Reith's control. This bill is before us under the transport portfolio, but this is not about transport reform. This is about changing the basis upon which conditions of employment of Australian workers in the seafaring industry are determined. Most of the provisions in this bill do not endure the support of the opposition. (Extension of time granted)

The second reading speech included the sorts of words that the minister at the table, the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, Mr Tuckey, also used—`Australian seafarers enjoy exceptionally good working conditions'. That is what Minister Anderson said when he introduced the bill. It was pretty much the same as what Minister Reith said when he introduced it last year. What we have is an attempt to change that. In the view of the government, they have it too good. In the view of the government, this is the way that you get rid of their—in their words—`exceptionally good working conditions'.

Let us talk about the conditions that exist in the seafaring industry. Items 1 through 5 deal with the removal of articles of agreement, and I should say something about articles of agreement. The articles of agreement exist because by act of parliament the Australian parliament has accepted for decades that to regulate this industry and to ensure that the worst practices in the seafaring industry around the globe are not pushed on to our Australian seafarers we should have a system of engagement, we should have a system of certification of qualifications and skills and we should have a system of discharge so that those people who want to work in the industry are trained to do so and are competent.

Against that background, we see the advice of the parliament's committees that tell us these things from their investigations. In 1992 the committee report to the parliament identified maltreatment including denial of food, the provision of inadequate food, the bashing of crew members by ships officers and the maintenance of two pay books—one for official records and another one that kept records of the international transport workers levels of pay just in case they were required to show them. Then there was the non-payment of wages or non-payment of overtime, the inadequate accommodation or washing facilities, the sexual molestation or the rape or depriving access to medical care. All of these things have been advised to this parliament in formal committee reports. That was the view in 1992. It was confirmed in each of the subsequent reports, including the one provided only last year.

The government says that this industry is like any other and it does not matter that the parliament has been given advice that these problems exist in the industry today. We are not talking about a bygone era. We are not talking about practices of the past. We are talking about practices today in the seafaring industry. Knowing that is the problem, this government says, `But that industry deserves no special consideration. It should be dealt with the same as all others and wages and conditions should be determined by the Workplace Relations Act.'

As I said in my speech during the second reading debate, and it comes as no surprise to the government, we do not support the Workplace Relations Act. We do not support it for any workers, no matter where they are. But we certainly do not support it for people in an industry that is unique—absolutely unique. There is no other industry in civilian life where a person says goodbye to the family at the door of their home, goes off to work and might come home about three or four months later after they have been required to travel on board a ship to other ports around the country or around the globe. That is not a standard employment arrangement. Nor is it a standard employment arrangement where people who do this find themselves living and working 24 hours a day with the same group of people in very close quarters. It happens in military life, but it is extremely rare in civilian employment. Living and working on those ships is more than a place of employment; it is a social system. It is in fact their entire social life as well as their employment life.

Concern about the safety component of what goes on at sea is also different to the sorts of jobs that this government argues are the same as any other. For example, the International Labour Organisation observed in their conference in 1996 the problem confronting shipowners and seafarers with lost ships at sea and the threat to life that comes from having poor ships and having poorly qualified crew. (Extension of time granted) At the 1996 ILO convention, the Director-General of the ILO said this about the nature of this industry:

The dangers to which shipowners and governments are exposed are financial or political in nature, but seafarers are exposed to physical risks which threaten their very lives. It has, for example, been emphasised that since 1994 180 ships of more than 500 tonnes have been lost at sea, causing the death of 1,200 seafarers and many passengers. In the first six months of 1996, twice as many human lives were lost at sea than in the whole of 1995.

The simple fact of life is that this is an industry in which thousands of people lose their lives at sea because of poor management, poor ships, poor training. That does not happen in Australia precisely because we have this sort of legislation protecting Australian workers and requiring standards to be met. Unfortunately, it is those very standards this government is in the process of seeking to remove.

There are a range of specific provisions. I have already outlined that the opposition is opposed to items 1 to five, all of which deal with the articles of agreement. Item 6 repeals the definition of `desertion'. The opposition will be supporting that although, given the way in which the vote is going to occur today, we will not have the opportunity to make that clear by vote. But I guess that will be dealt with when it reaches another place. Item 7 deals with the definition of `proper return to ports'. We understand that these matters are now effectively handled via enterprise negotiations and award arrangements. We will support item 7.

Item 8 again deals with articles of agreement—the issue which I have basically been speaking about to date. It is our intention to oppose item 8, which requires the master or the officer or the seafarer to produce certificates concerning their qualifications.

There is another aspect in relation to this. The qualifications and the certification of qualifications is vitally important to the safety and welfare of seafarers. It is protected in current legislation and proposed to be removed by this bill. The problem of false certificates is well understood in the industry. It has been the subject of parliamentary committee reports that I have mentioned that have identified it as a major concern in the industry.

I want to repeat a quote by Captain Bolitho, the former Chairman of the Australian Shipping Line, in a speech he made in only August last year. He was speaking at a conference, and he made the observation that Professor David Moresby of the Institute of Marine Studies at the University of Plymouth had demonstrated that, for $US300, it is possible to purchase a master's certificate, perfect in every detail, except that the name is left blank for you to fill in. Captain Bolitho went on to say:
Approximately 20 per cent of the world's seafarers are from the Philippines and . . . 90 per cent of them are sailing on worthless papers . . .

We have a situation where key figures in the industry will tell you that today about one in five people sailing ships are doing it with false certificates. This government's response to that problem of having one in five unsafe, unqualified seafarers is to remove the protection in our legislation. They say, `Well, the employer will now have the right to determine this.' Of course, employers are going to check this rigorously!

We know from past experience of all industries that, in this industry, that is not the case. There are too many shipowners and operators who will gladly accept someone who does not have the skills, provided they will work for little reward. There are only too many people in countries around the world happy to sign on board to get a job, to get out of the country, to get an opportunity in another life maybe somewhere else in the world, and to do that in poor conditions—in conditions we would not accept—and on false certificates. (Extension of time granted) We will be opposing item 8 for the reasons I have just mentioned.

Item 9 deals with fees for the supply of seafarers. At present, we have a provision that creates an offence for demanding or receiving remuneration for providing seafarers for employment. This section also includes a definition of a seafarer as including a person seeking employment as a seafarer. We will oppose this provision as well.

Item 10 deals with the current restriction on handling of cargo or ballast. At the moment, crew are not permitted by law to handle cargo or ballast in unloading ships. We will move an amendment to that provision to enable crew to deal with ballast in port, but we will not be supporting a shift in the law to deregulate the situation with the handling of cargo. This is an important provision, and interesting for a number of reasons. It actually goes to part of the problem this government has in dealing with this issue.

I mentioned at the outset the lack of consultation this government has been involved in in pursuing the matter. This is not the end of the road in the government's legislative program for changing the Navigation Act. The Navigation Act is the subject of a number of reviews, and the government have announced their intention to proceed with a second major rewrite of that act.

The concern that I have is that this bill deals solely with and targets the conditions of seafarers. Had the government genuinely involved in a process of consultation all of the stakeholders—not just asked them to make submissions to committees the government set up, but actually involved them directly in the process of deliberation—and had the government put together a total package of genuine reform, it may well have found a greater willingness on the part of those in the industry and on the part of the opposition here, the Labor Party, to deal differently with this matter. But it has not done that. Nor has it come to it with clean hands. Nor has it come to it without a record.

This government's record of dealing with people in the seafaring and stevedoring industry is extremely poor. It has left deep scars that will not easily go away. Therefore, we view the proposals in item 10 as an attempt by the government to continue with its obsession of attacking people on the waterfront. Through the Patrick debacle last year, we saw the government's willingness to try to wage war on the waterfront. In fact, this provision will enable that to continue in a way that would be very destructive for Australian workers.

Were this amendment to go through, particularly in the context of the other safeguards this bill seeks to remove, there effectively would be no restriction on the sorts of unqualified underpaid crew to which I have just referred being involved in work not just as seafarers but also as stevedores on Australian ports. We would be saying to those people currently working on the waterfront, `Your job is now to be done by anybody who any shipowner regards as good enough to crew their ship.'

We are not willing to sign up to that item. It is a savage attack on people on the waterfront which is only thinly disguised in this bill. Its motivation is clearly exposed by this government's previous approach to the industry, and particularly to the MUA and people working in that field. So we oppose item 10.

Item 11 deals with articles of agreement. It is a straightforward change in nomenclature, and we support it. Item 12 again deals with articles of agreement and goes to the process of how they operate. We support the continuation of articles of agreement and are opposed to their elimination. (Extension of time granted) Therefore, we will continue to oppose that item which forms an important part of the operations of articles of agreement.

We oppose item 13. It seeks to remove the Marine Council, and we see that as a retrograde step. The council performs important functions, and we see the need for its retention. Item 14 deals with the discharge of seafarers. We will seek to amend that. The amendment has been circulated and, given the constraints of time, I do not propose to talk about it.

Item 15 deals with crewing details. This concerns a requirement of the employer to notify AMSA of the details of changes in the crew. We think that is one of the safeguards for Australian seafarers which ensures that they are not exposed to the worst elements of this industry internationally. Accordingly, we oppose item 15.

Item 16 again deals with the operations of articles of agreement, as many of these amendments do. For all the reasons I have previously stated, we oppose item 16 and support the retention of articles of agreement.

Item 17 deals with the discharge of seafarers. At present the bill provides for the master to provide discharge certificates. These discharge certificates form an important part of the process of recording the experience, training and skill of seafarers. We think that also is an important safeguard to be retained and, therefore, we oppose item 17.

There are a range of sections of the act that are amended by item 18. They deal with wages and the way in which wages are paid, and so on. Whilst having some concern, frankly, about its removal, we support it. I understand that these matters are now adequately dealt with via enterprise agreements. Item 19 also deals with wages and, as with item 18, we support it.

Item 20 is another amendment that seeks to change the situation with articles of agreement. It is actually consequential amendments on those more substantial matters that I have addressed already. We oppose it. We support item 21. It concerns the discharge of seafarers and repeals section 88, which is a section providing compensation for premature discharge. We are happy to support the government in that. Item 22 also deals with the discharge of seafarers, and we support it.

We oppose item 23. It too deals with articles of agreement. It is a consequential amendment that follows the more substantial amendments mentioned earlier. We oppose item 24. This item deals with wages for sick seafarers who are left at shore. Frankly, we see no reason why that provision should be removed. It provides a legal protection for seafarers who are ill and left in other parts of the world. We see no reason why that should be removed and why that protection should not be afforded to Australian seafarers. We oppose item 25.

We oppose item 26. It requires a seafarer to provide an address and report for medical examination when left on shore. Frankly, we think that is a sensible arrangement, and we are not quite sure why the government proposes to remove that other than to pursue its deregulation agenda.

Item 27 deals with the Marine Council. It repeals section 138, which permits the Marine Council to consider plans for accommodation in ships and make recommendations to the minister in relation to that accommodation. Notwithstanding the advice of parliamentary committees that have identified accommodation as a problem, we understand that this matter has been properly, and is continuing to be effectively, dealt with in enterprise negotiations. Therefore, we are willing to support it, although with some degree of concern.

Item 28 deals with discharging seafarers. It will be supported by the opposition. (Extension of time granted) I will very quickly go through the remaining matters in the five minutes available, given the hour and given that it is the last day of the sitting. We will be looking to deal with this matter more fully in another place. We will be supporting item 29, which proposes changes to the operations of the wages system. We will oppose item 30, which are articles of agreement. Item 31 deals with some changes to the wages system, deleting the words `or the certificate of a proper authority stating that certain seafarers be shipped in the ship'. We think it is important to have those protections there, so we will oppose that item. It is our intention to oppose items 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38 and 39.

We have some support for item 40, although given the government's intentions to remove the articles of agreement I think we will have to oppose it. Item 41, which proposes the discharging of seafarers, makes some minor adjustments which we are willing to support. Similarly, we will support item 42, which deals with coasting ships. We understand that these matters are being dealt with adequately at enterprise negotiation level. I do have some concerns about the removal of item 42, but at this stage we are willing to lend our support to it.

We will support item 43, which is a consequential amendment to an earlier matter. The same applies to item 44 and item 45. We will oppose item 46 because it deals with the articles of agreement that we believe should be kept. We have an amendment which has been circulated in my name to item 47, which we will get to shortly, I am sure. Item 48 changes the operation of the Marine Council. We believe the Marine Council is important for the protection of seafarers' rights, and we will therefore oppose this item.

This bill is an important bill. In my view, the government should not have sought to bring it forward ahead of the other more wide-ranging reforms that are occurring in the industry. The industry has over the years demonstrated its willingness to participate constructively in reform. We saw that during the period of the Labor government in the nineties where crewing of Australian ships was nearly halved. That occurred as a result of negotiations that involved all stakeholders in meaningful discussions. Changes in work practices were agreed to, and significant benefits to the industry flowed. Unfortunately, this government has not adopted that inclusive approach to dealing with this legislation and is dealing particularly with the workers in this industry. It has decided for reasons best known to itself to set upon workers in the stevedoring and related industries. We can see that again in this piece of legislation.

This is an important industry for Australia. We are an island continent. Our seafaring trade is critically important to us. It should not be dealt with as some sort of political football or ideologically driven agenda of this government to crush the MUA. Frankly, too much of what is in this bill is designed to do just that. It is an ongoing war that this government wants to have with the MUA. We have indicated our willingness to support some of the proposals in this bill because we think they bring things up to date and get rid of some anachronisms. We will not support, however, this government's vendetta to drive the MUA into the ground. We will not support provisions which seek to have unqualified, fraudulently certified crews of ships of convenience used to replace Australian standards—and that is precisely what this bill will facilitate—nor will we support workers of that kind with fraudulently acquired certification used to replace wharfies on Australian wharves, and that is what this bill provides.

I urge the government to reconsider their approach to this bill. I urge them to reconsider their approach to reform in the industry and become more inclusive. From the opposition's point of view, we will look constructively at that. We will seek to examine the bill in greater detail with more time in the Senate. I will be watching closely the deliberations of that committee as we consider our ongoing position.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Because there were other matters than the amendments dealt with, there are some aspects of the response that I have already given that are worthy of repetition. Firstly, in my response to the second reading, the words I used were:

speech.para: Also, section 16 of the act covering the problems of forged certificates is being retained and is not affected by the amendments in the bill.

All those comments that were made in that regard have no relevance. In responding to the remarks of the member for Brisbane, we were given a litany of problems in the seafaring industry affecting Australian workers. If they exist, they are a fault of the system we are trying to replace. We are trying to replace it with a workplace agreement that gives the union and its members the opportunity to go through some of these issues and say, `I do not find that acceptable. If I am to travel for these periods of time, this is the deal I want.'

In the days before there was any interest by trade unions in some of the more remote areas of Western Australia, I dealt with truck drivers and many other people who used to take about five minutes to tell me how much money they wanted, how they wanted it paid and what the deal was. They were negotiated in that system, because the last thing you could get away with was to offer them the award. They would not have a bar of it. This is the opportunity for people to get out of the straitjacket system that, on the evidence of the member for Brisbane, is not working. Hansard will record all the things he said that happens. He talked about people getting raped and people getting beaten up. That is the current system.

So there is good reason for the opportunities that we offer, including in negotiations for employment contracts under the Workplace Relations Act. In all of this, I think Australian workers going to sea will, over time, find all sorts of ways in which they could do that better, including how they deal with their family—but that is for another day. The member for Brisbane said that no-one else leaves home and does not come home for three or four months. I just thought of geologists, drilling contractors and, tragically—as we have been reminded—certified accountants who go overseas—
Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Many of those people who go overseas for extended periods, particularly people like geologists, do not live in particularly salubrious conditions and they do not live with their family.

speech.para: Let me say something about the amendments that have been proposed by the opposition. The first of those reads:
(1) Schedule 1, item 10, page 4 (lines 12 and 13), omit the item, substitute:
Omit `or ballast'.

This amendment is unacceptable to the government as it retains the restrictions on a ship's crew handling cargo. This is purely and simply an industrial demarcation issue about whether seafarers should be allowed to drive ship winches. It dates back to a dispute in 1911 and has no place in a modern navigation act. The second amendment reads:
(2) Schedule 1, item 14, page 5 (lines 1 and 2), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the subsections.

This amendment is unacceptable to the government as it retains the six-month limit on the length of continuous service under an agreement and includes requirements concerning a shipowner's obligation to pay the costs of returning a seafarer to his or her agreed return port.

The government considers that the length of service of a seafarer on a particular ship and other related issues are matters for negotiation between employers and employees under company employment agreements. It is not necessary or appropriate to have this type of provision in the navigation act, particularly as the Australian shipping industry now operates under company employment arrangements. The third amendment reads:
(3) Schedule 1, item 47, omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the paragraphs.

There is no section identified as section 377. We think that the opposition probably referred to 377C, and if that is being referred to then the proposed amendment is unacceptable to the government. (Extension of time granted) The amendment is unacceptable to the government as it presupposes that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority will continue to be involved with the details of agreements, as provided for in subsection 46(2A).

This will not be the case as the government proposes to repeal subsection 46(2A) and amend section 46 so as to provide greater flexibility for employers and employees to enter into company agreements best suited to an individual company. The government also proposes to repeal all of section 76 dealing with seafarers account of wages on discharge. The requirement for seafarers to be formally discharged from each ship by signing off the traditional articles of agreement will be repealed under the bill.

Furthermore, the opposition's amendment presupposes that the Marine Council, referred to in section 47, is going to continue in existence. This will not be the case as the government proposes to abolish the Marine Council and the various provisions referring to it. As mentioned in the explanatory memorandum—item 48, under company employment—it is the responsibility of the employer to determine issues that have previously been dealt with by the Marine Council. Under company employment there is no place or need for a government appointed body such as the Marine Council.

That is the government's response to the amendments. We note that the opposition proposes to oppose, I think, more sections of the bill than it intends to support. We conclude our remarks by saying that we think that this is legislation that will be progressive for the industry and for those who work in it because they will have an opportunity to put their own case through any representative they choose, including the union, as to the conditions they expect when they take a workplace agreement with a shipowner. I think those improvements will be worthwhile in terms of the operations of the Australian industry. Let us hope that it will deliver the sort of competitiveness that would reverse the ongoing decline that has existed in Australia's shipping industry.

We have been reminded that we are an island continent. We were often reminded of value adding. Value adding to our raw materials can simply be achieved by owning and operating the ship that delivers them to a foreign port. We have had a death wish as a nation, assisted by the MUA and others, to drive this industry into obscurity. It is one of the most competitive in the world, but modern technology makes it possible to pay people high wages, give them good conditions and still operate a ship efficiently. All of these issues are best determined between the employees who go to sea and the people who invest in the ships. That is exactly what the government intends through its new arrangements. I thank the House.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Tuckey)—by leave—read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Committee of Privileges concerning an application for the publication of a response to a reference made in the House of Representatives.
—As required by resolution of the House, I table copies of notification of alterations of interests and statement of registrable interests received during the period 7 December 1998 to 31 March 1999.

debate.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I want to address concerns I have heard from universities within and beyond my electorate on the proposed voluntary student unionism. This is not a law about fairness and equity. It is an unbridled ideologically based attack on student associations because of an apparent prejudice that the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has about anything that has the name `union' attached to it. Let me read part of a letter from the Orange Agricultural College—that well-known hotbed of neo-Marxist revisionism and the alma mater of several National Party notables, including a recently retired former transport minister. The letter says:

speech.para: Mr Kemp's anti union ideology is not relevant as far as we are concerned.
Our student association is in the business of providing the best possible student services we can and introduction of VSU will ensure our student services cease.

The minister argues that part-time and distance education students are the ones who most resist payment of these fees. That is not the message I am getting. Many of the services offered by Charles Sturt University in Bathurst, Wagga and Albury have special relevance to distance students, including Austudy and HECS advice, transport, residential school services and so on. Other services offered by MASC, the Mitchell Association of Student Councils, at CSU Bathurst include accident insurance, desktop publishing, a courtesy bus, and O-week organisation—over 50 important services. That is hardly the stuff of left-wing, anti-government activism. The Vice-Chancellor of ANU, Deane Terrell, says:
It is impossible to stop people who have not paid their fees from running onto an oval or from sitting in a cafeteria.

This debate about voluntary versus involuntary unionism would be academic if it were not for the more sinister intent of forcing universities to introduce voluntary student unionism by making it a condition of government funding that a university not raise a fee from a student that is not directly related to the course.

Grants from the Department of Education, Training and Youth Affairs have already decreased from $4.79 billion in 1996 to $4.1 billion this year and are proposed to drop to $3.9 billion in 2001. The Australian vice-chancellors say that the withdrawal of government funding over three years to 2001 represents a reduction of $1,070 a student. The minister would argue that the gap has been made up from HECS. However, even allowing for HECS increases, the reduction is $234 a student and set to drop by a significant amount if these proposals go through.

The arts faculty at ANU, for one, has been decimated in recent years as scarce funds are directed to more market oriented courses. Research now depends largely on tied government grants and funds paid under contract by the corporate sector. The anthropology and archaeology departments at ANU are being ground down to a shadow of their former roles. They might soon themselves be the subjects of archaeological digs to discover what was taught in an age when pure research for other than commercial ends enriched a civilisation.

I had the privilege of attending the 1999 Mulvaney Lecture by Professor Jim Allen at ANU last week at which one of our foremost archaeologists reviewed research from the past four decades and outlined how that research has declined alarmingly. He said:

. . . the decimation of that department last year in the name of economic rationalism, and present attacks on the remnant which is left, may permanently destroy a legacy which might never have evolved in the state universities . . . we must stop the dismemberment of archaeology in the ANU.

And I would add the arts and the classics too. The market will not deliver the type of educated people we need in this country and the government's reliance on the market delivering quality tertiary education is further underlined by the extraordinary payback voluntary student unionism legislation.

The thinking behind that legislation is 25 years out of date, locked in the era of the Vietnam War or the Cold War when student agitation really did move public opinion and embarrassed governments. And why not? But I guess the minister can sleep peacefully knowing that the political extremists of universities like Orange Agricultural College, which I have named, have finally been caught out for daring to use the student association supplied photocopier to copy last year's exam paper. No more will these dangerous extremists be able to foster anti-government sentiments at an intervarsity sports competition!

talk.start.para: —I rise on the issue of the so-called needle exchange program or what most concerned people in the community refer to as the needle distribution program. This initiative was deceptively introduced into the community as a so-called mechanism to control the spread of HIV-AIDS. It has grown into an industry that is supplying the tools of trade—needles—to administer the illegal body destroying drug heroin. This initiative assisted in creating an epidemic of hepatitis C in Australia—an issue which I will come back to shortly.

speech.para: In the state of New South Wales alone, the needle-syringe exchange program, first implemented in 1998 by the New South Wales Health Department, has seen an expansion from the distribution of 2.3 million needle- syringes in that year to approximately 9.2 million needle-syringes in the 1997-98 financial year. Today in New South Wales we see an expansion of this chain to 310 public outlets and 520 participating pharmacies offering free needle-syringes to injecting drug users, including juveniles under the age of 16.

There is no age barrier to children under 16 years of age accessing needle distribution programs in New South Wales, nor indeed in some other states. Health ministers responsible for the delivery of implements used to administer illegal addictive drugs such as heroin need to have a close look at what, in their attempts to justify the catchcry of the needle-syringe program of controlling the spread of HIV-AIDS, they are doing to assist in the expansion of the illegal distribution chain and, more importantly, what it is doing to young people. I will certainly have more to say on that issue at a later date when I address the issue of heroin in our society.

Let me now turn to the issue of the spread of the highly infectious hepatitis C, which has infected 200,000 Australians, half of whom live in New South Wales and many of whom will have symptomatic illnesses as a result of that infection. In December 1998, the Hepatitis C Council of New South Wales estimated that around 11,000 new HCV infections are occurring across the nation each year, or 30 new infections a day—and again, half of these are in New South Wales.

Some 90 per cent of these new infections occur through blood to blood contact resulting from people sharing equipment used for injecting drug use. So much for the argument that throwing needle-syringes at addicts will control the spread of highly infectious viruses. HIV-AIDS is not increasing because the homosexual community is not practising safe sex. It has been, in my view, and nothing has been forthcoming which disputes that view. Besides, being a homosexual certainly does not mean you are automatically an injecting drug user, which tends to be the impression forced on the community by pro-drug advocates.
Let me now refer to the policy and procedures manual which drives the needle syringe exchange program in New South Wales. Paragraph 1 on page 4 of that document says:

The NSEP is based on harm reduction rather than abstention: That is, it is primarily concerned not to minimise injecting drug use as such but rather to minimise the potential HIV-related harm flowing from such use.
This policy document advises all NSEP to adhere to the following:
They do not give to police any information regarding activities of IDU or dealers.
. Any requests from the media regarding the program must be forwarded to their supervisor.

. Staff must be made aware that adverse media can restrict the use of the service by IDU and jeopardise the program. Policies which are deliberately impeding our law enforcement agencies from vital intelligence on drug distribution.

This harm reduction strategy has failed. It has failed since 1985 when `harm reduction' was the cornerstone of federal government policy in Australia. Governments and their advisers have pursued and enforced the theory that promoting `safe' drug use will increase the health of young Australians. Needles to addicts, marijuana as medicine, responsible drug use education and softening drug law enforcement are harm reduction policies.

Isn't `harm reduction' really the former failed `responsible use' policy that gave birth to the problems we have on this drug issue today? It certainly does not seek to prevent harm or cure harm. What it does do is seek to reduce harm to the users and the dealers, at considerable cost to society. What is the cost behind this harm reduction agenda? Could it be power, politics and money, or is it just another indication of total incompetence mixed with a lack of political will to take total control of problems such as the need to ensure drugs are removed from our communities?

Politicians in the US are aware of the problems needle syringe distribution programs are creating, with increases in the availability and use of heroin. In September 1997 the US House of Representatives voted to strengthen the ban on the federal funding for needle exchange programs. In the previous year the US Centre for Disease Control reported that more than 14 million syringes were distributed in the US through needle exchange programs. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —Between the rising of parliament this evening and the resumption of parliament for the budget session, Australia will celebrate its final Anzac Day this century. Like most Australians, I take great pride in the fact that Anzac Day has increased in significance as a national day over recent decades. I believe that more Australians look upon Anzac Day as a national day more than any other. After all, it does not have the significance of a white Australia conquering black Australia. Actually, in stark contrast to that, Anzac Day is an all encompassing day and all Australians—all those people who have chosen to live here, who admire democracy, who admire our way of life—are included in Anzac Day. I think that is the great thing that Anzac Day has developed into.

speech.para: But, unfortunately, there is a change taking place in our community that is tending to denigrate Anzac Day. I talk about increasing commercialisation as large multinational retailers, with their insatiable thirst for the almighty dollar, want to thrust 24-hour retailing on to the Australian community.
